note.body:
Thanks for a bug report. If I understand correctly, it's a `/usr/bin/msgmerge` error, thus its problem, is it not? Is there any other project using it, which does not break? The log does not show it being called, but it can be a ninja build thing, hiding "boring" parts.

> libgomp: Thread creation failed: Resource temporarily unavailable

The `libgomp` is nothing eds uses directly. The error message explains what's going on here. It (whichever _it_) tried to create a new thread, but the system rejected as no enough resources are available for it now.

The eds can build many things in parallel, it's not a simple project. Supposing you cannot add more resources to the builder, I suggest to try to disable parallel build of the eds, at least as a test. It'll slow down your pipeline significantly.

note.body:
So when there is no text in the input element, there is a `div.placeholder` element containing that "Email, phone, or Skype" text placed within the input element:

![Screenshot_From_2024-12-10_09-28-11](/uploads/b557218f4ccb8bd6f47bd0696fb47abd/Screenshot_From_2024-12-10_09-28-11.png)

That div is not itself an input element, and it hit tests accordingly, which is why the context menu items for an input element are not displayed. But you can work around the problem by right clicking very close to the bottom of what appears to be the input area, which is within the input element but outside of the div:

![Screencast_From_2024-12-10_09-22-29](/uploads/8384a8bc4a53000a76534a55c027579c/Screencast_From_2024-12-10_09-22-29.webm)

Sadly this screencast does not show my mouse cursor, but you can maybe tell from the slightly different position of the context menu.

When you type a character, the placeholder div is removed and the entire input element will pass the hit test.

I don't know whether this is a bug or not. I think it would be reasonable to say that any elements within an input element should hit test as an input element, but maybe that would cause some other sort of bug or violate some web standard. No clue. Feel free to report on WebKit Bugzilla if you want.

note.body:
Thanks for a bug report. I'm not sure from the above about the consequences, specifically how the account was configured and what the outcome was. Is it that:
* when the account is configured in the GNOME Online Accounts (in the GNOME Settings), then neither Evolution nor gnome-contacts shows any CardDAV book, but
* when the account is configured directly in the Evolution, using the same address (URL) as in the GNOME Online Accounts, then the book is shown?

You can configure the book in the Evolution in two ways. One is when you enter direct link to it, or you can configure the account, in which case you get everything from the server (if you've multiple books, then all of them under one account). The later is similar to what is done for the accounts configured by the GNOME Online Accounts; you can do it by Edit->Accounts->Add->Collection Account, or File->New->Collection Account, where you just fill the URL and then let it detect the available sources.

note.body:
No clue. Not having a Paste context menu item sounds pretty strange.

 * Are there any suspicious errors printed when running Evolution in a terminal? The output should be clean.
 * Is Evolution's web process extension loaded properly? Web process extensions may edit the context menu, and occasionally weird bugs might prevent an extension from loading properly.

My guess would be that the hit test is failing for unknown reason, causing WebKit or Evolution to not realize that a form element is selected and therefore not present the form elements. But I've never heard of a bug like this before.

A screenshot of Evolution displaying the broken context menu might be useful.

target_title: CalDAV: Do not use SCHEDULE-AGENT parameter

note.body:
The above commits are for 3.55.1+ and 3.54.3+

I decided to not save the ACKNOWLEDGE property on CalDAV servers which to autoschedule and I disabled use of the SCHEDULE-AGENT parameter when modifying the components due to this unneeded side effect (server sending false cancellation notices, even though dictated by the RFC 6638).

target_title: CalDAV: Do not use SCHEDULE-AGENT parameter

note.body:
>  It qualifies, from my point of view, to the <Absent> row of the linked RFC 6638 section, but the Fastmail server behaves like there is set the parameter with the SERVER value. The table distinguishes between the original component has "the SCHEDULE-AGENT set to SERVER" and "the SCHEDULE-AGENT parameter is missing (absent), thus behave like the SERVER is set".

No, I did re-read the section and the absent/removed is for the whole ATTENDEE property, not for the SCHEDULE-AGENT parameter. Meaning the Fastmail's implementation is correct.

> The CalDAV backend needs to reset the `SCHEDULE-AGENT` to the `SERVER` value from the `CLIENT` value (not just to remove it, because that does not notify the attendees).

Hrm, no, it cannot do it, that's wrong, because after that, when another reminder is dismissed, then it would change the parameter from the `SERVER` to the `CLIENT`, which does the cancellation.

Frankly, I do not know why the server is supposed to send the cancellations in this case (as requested by the RFC). It can generate two confusing meeting updates, one cancellation from the server, another real update from the client.

That being said, the use of the `SCHEDULE-AGENT` to not send meeting change notifications by the server on a reminder dismiss is wrong (or for anything else, to avoid the messages).

target_title: CalDAV: Do not use SCHEDULE-AGENT parameter

note.body: Err, see below

target_title: CalDAV: Do not use SCHEDULE-AGENT parameter

note.body:
Okay, the https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/evolution-data-server/-/issues/568#note_2289482 has no ATTENDEE, which confused me. This new log has them.

From my point of view, it's a bug on the Fastmail side. There are two things:  
a) there is no cancellation requested by the evolution-alarm-notify, it only adds a property to a VALARM sub-component and that's all;  
b) the attendees contain `SCHEDULE-AGENT=CLIENT` on save, which tells the server to not send any scheduling messages, because the client took care of it. More about that is in the [RFC 6638](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc6638#section-3.2.1.2).

Your log shows there is no `SCHEDULE-AGENT` parameter on the attendees, while the `PUT` adds it. It qualifies, from my point of view, to the `<Absent>` row of the linked RFC 6638 section, but the Fastmail server behaves like there is set the parameter with the `SERVER` value. The table distinguishes between the original component has "the `SCHEDULE-AGENT` set to `SERVER`" and "the `SCHEDULE-AGENT` parameter is missing (absent), thus behave _like_ the `SERVER` is set".

Nonetheless, I see the CalDAV backend in the evolution-data-server doesn't work well too. I though the `SCHEDULE-AGENT` is a one-time thing, used on the PUT and removed by the server immediately, but I see it behaves differently. It will be a problem. I do not know how to dismiss a reminder also on the server, without notifying the attendees about a change they do not need to know. by saving the dismiss to the server you should not be notified about the event on other machines/devices, when you dismiss it in the evolution-alarm-notify. The CalDAV backend needs to reset the `SCHEDULE-AGENT` to the `SERVER` value from the `CLIENT` value (not just to remove it, because that does not notify the attendees).

target_title: CalDAV: Do not use SCHEDULE-AGENT parameter

note.body: Did you remove any `ATTENDEE` from the component or it had none, please? I do not see any cancellation in that component. The timestamp of the log says the PUT was done at `01:19:00 UTC Nov 20`, while the `ACKNOWLEDGED` property claims the time `01:18:48 UTC`, thus 12 seconds earlier. This property is set by the evolution-alarm-notify, when a reminder is dismissed. If I'm not mistaken, it's done only after a user action, not deliberately on its own, maybe except when cleaning up old (and ancient) reminders, to not have stored too many of them in the GSettings. These changes are not supposed to generate any notices to the attendees, especially after the https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/evolution-data-server/-/issues/551

target_title: CalDAV: Do not use SCHEDULE-AGENT parameter

note.body: Each PUT should be for a single event. It should contain the event content. I suppose each is for a different event, but I can be wrong, thus (at least) one should be for the cancelled meeting. You can recognize it by the `SUMMARY` line. I'd like to know what had been PUT to the server. If you could remove the sensitive/private information, like the summary/description, email addresses, simply anything you consider private from it, and attach it here, please? Make sure you won't remove any properties/parameters, remove only private information. Being there anything not readable by a human being, delete it too. Some parts can be encoded (like some base64-encoded values), readable by the machine, which you do not want to expose too.

note.body:
Just wanted to chime in that I have the exact same issue here. 

The logs that Fastmail sent me were:
We received a cancellation from your end a few days after the event invitation was sent. We were also able to track down the logs of how the cancellation was sent.

The logs seem to indicate that the second RSVP was triggered from a calendar app that advertises itself as "Evolution/3.52.4". Here's the log that shows the change being made to the event at the time(in EDT): `2024-10-18T12:22:34.027326-04:00 phl-imap-04 (info) slotpi04n18/httpcaldav[289104]:  phl-frontend-02.phl.internal [10.202.2.161] as "myemailaddress@email.com" with "Evolution/3.52.4" via SESSIONID=<slotpi04n18-1729268553-289104-5-15391066243366863781>; "PUT /dav/calendars/user/myemailaddress@email.com/4472276c-4763-4a50-bc90-a2b903702ff7/add565d2-ca9f-4294-88be-43ac21d63fcc.ics HTTP/1.1" (auth=Basic; prefer=return=minimal; x-trace-id="ti_a7735ac6455d53579a5a873ba854581b") => "HTTP/1.1 204 No Content" [timing: cmd=0.039526 net=0.002459 total=0.041985]`

It appears that you have a Linux device that's running the Evolution calendar app, and the cancellation was triggered from it. Unfortunately, we can't trace the exact actions that led to this, but it's possible that this is an edge-case bug with that app.

Being it inside the web page, then it's under the control of the web itself. I'd guess the context menu may always contain the Paste option, but I can be wrong. This context menu is not provided by the data server code, it's all in the WebKitGTK.

You can open the OAuth2 wizard in an "external" (full/real) browser by clicking such button beside the URL above the wizard. After that the window content changes and allows to enter the authorization code, which is the result of the wizard, but I see it's not what you want to paste, it's something else. I misplaced it, I'm sorry.

I'm afraid adding an extra `Paste` button somewhere into the window would look odd. The web content is fully dictated by the web site. The context menu is also handled by the web site and by the WebKitGTK. I'm afraid there is not much the data server code can do about this.

target_title: Fails to build/link against icu 76.1

note.body:
```
diff --git a/CMakeLists.txt b/CMakeLists.txt
index 64ce2e206..b10c72781 100644
--- a/CMakeLists.txt
+++ b/CMakeLists.txt
@@ -376,12 +376,12 @@ endif(WIN32)
 # ICU started shipping pkg-config files but it's not present
 # on many systems, if we don't find the pkg-config
 # file then let's fallback on a manual check
-pkg_check_modules(ICU icu-i18n)
+pkg_check_modules(ICU icu-uc)
 
 if(NOT ICU_FOUND)
        CHECK_INCLUDE_FILE(unicode/ucol.h HAVE_UNICODE_UCOL_H)
        if(NOT HAVE_UNICODE_UCOL_H)
-               message(FATAL_ERROR "ICU unicode/ucol.h not found; icu-i18n is required")
+               message(FATAL_ERROR "ICU unicode/ucol.h not found; icu-uc is required")
        endif(HAVE_UNICODE_UCOL_H)
 
        set(CMAKE_REQUIRED_LIBRARIES "-licui18n -licuuc -licudata")
@@ -393,7 +393,7 @@ if(NOT ICU_FOUND)
                set(ICU_CFLAGS -D_REENTRANT)
                set(ICU_LIBS "-licui18n -licuuc -licudata")
        else(HAVE_UCOL_OPEN)
-               message(FATAL_ERROR "Failed to find icu-i18n, install its development files or build them first")
+               message(FATAL_ERROR "Failed to find icu-uc, install its development files or build them first")
        endif(HAVE_UCOL_OPEN)
 endif(NOT ICU_FOUND)
 
```

Would work as an upstream patch - it works at least also with ICU 75 and presumably older - but there untested

Thanks for a bug report. I do not think the evolution-data-server should anyhow validate the data saved by the client. It's client's response to produce valid data.

target_title: Fails to build/link against icu 76.1

note.body:
I added this to the spec file:

```
+%if %{pkg_vcmp libicu-devel >= 76.1}
+%dnl Adapt build system to ICU 76.1 - we now need to link icu-uc, no longer icu-i18n
+%dnl https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/evolution-data-server/-/issues/574
+sed -i 's/icu-i18n/icu-uc &/' CMakeLists.txt
+%endif
```

which works - but this is not suitable for upstream

So, yes - with icu 76.1 we need icu-uc (likely also earlier, but there it was masked as `pkg-config --libs icu-i18n` included `-licuuc`

target_title: Dialogs for certificate trust/authentication request are not configurable by EDS clients

note.body:
Thanks for a bug report. It's true the dialogs cannot be "configured" from the outside, which is for good, because that way they are consistent between applications and the user of the code does not need to reinvent the wheel. These are part of the `libedataserverui` library, which is built for both gtk3 and gtk4. Nobody forces anybody to use the `ECredentialsPrompter` structure, but it covers a lot of things which would be a pita to rewrite in every client, thus it exists and is offered.

Trying to override the `ECredentialsPrompterImpl` with some signal or anything is not good idea, it cannot be done in general and the implementation does its own specific steps to properly save the credentials and so on. Does for example Firefox allow to use your own credential prompt dialog? I do not mean in the web page, but the dialog itself, which can be shown when the site to be opened asks for the credentials.

I do not see a problem in using libadwaita for the gtk4 version of the library, it seems to be essential in the gtk4 world these days anyway. The thing is how to modify it. As the #451 already exists, I mark this a duplicate of it. It's waiting for a designer input at the moment.

I gave this a try and the Microsoft does not allow to connect a free account with Microsoft Graph API OAuth2 token, neither for POP nor for SMTP, they reject the token and redirect to the "old" OAuth2 gate, thus I'm sorry, no way for the POP connection.

Use IMAP and add an Edit->Message Filters->Incoming->
```
   Rule name: [ .... ]
   Rule type: [ Incoming ] For Account: [ otulook.com/hotmail.com ]
   Find items which match [ any of the following conditions ]
   [ Match All ]
   Then
   [ Move to Folder ] [ On This Computer/.... ]
```
and keep enabled filtering for this IMAP mail account and its Inbox.

target_title: CalDAV: Do not use SCHEDULE-AGENT parameter

note.body:
> Is there a way to run evolution-calendar-factory in debug mode at boot?

It's a bit more complicated, but it's doable. I think the easiest is to edit `/etc/environment` and add to it:
```
CALDAV_DEBUG=1
```
but I'm not sure whether the log output, which ends on the stdout, is caught by the journalctl.

You can replace the original binary (`/usr/libexec/evolution-calendar-factory` or the path the factory is stored in your distro) with a script, which will call the original binary with additional arguments. Something like the following, executed as root:
1. `mv /usr/libexec/evolution-calendar-factory /usr/libexec/evolution-calendar-factory.orig`
2. edit: `/usr/libexec/evolution-calendar-factory` and add to it:
```bash
#!/bin/bash
CALDAV_DEBUG=1 /usr/libexec/evolution-calendar-factory.orig "$@" &>/tmp/ecf.log
```
3. `chmod a+x /usr/libexec/evolution-calendar-factory`
4. restart the machine

target_title: CalDAV: Do not use SCHEDULE-AGENT parameter

note.body:
Aha, I wasn't sure, but it looks like you are using only the calendar part of the Fastmail, right? Thus even maybe you do not use the Evolution at all, but some other app for the calendaring, apart of their web interface, I guess.

The option for the server to do the invitation handling can be seen in the Evolution. I do not think the gnome-calendar exposes it anywhere.

If you can reproduce this easily, could you run the calendar factory with CalDAV debugging on:
```
  CALDAV_DEBUG=1 /usr/libexec/evolution-calendar-factory -w
```

(the actual path can differ in your distribution), and then reproduce the problem, please? I do not see any direct cancellation response code being set by the CalDAV calendar, the dismiss of the reminder is a modification of the event, not its cancellation, thus even if the Fastmail admins see there the cancellation comes from the CalDAV backend, I'd like to see what that request look like. For example the modification request should have set for each attendee an `SCHEDULE-AGENT` parameter of value `CLIENT`, telling the server to not do any scheduling mails. Similarly a `Schedule-Reply: F` header should be set for the same reason.

Please note the log contains raw communication between the CalDAV backend and the server, it can expose private information, like authorization tokens and the like, thus be careful what you share in the public, please.

Thanks for a bug report. Does the event contain any reminder? I do not think Evolution (or evolution-data-server) does cancel the event on its own, there might be some reason for it. The reminders dismiss could send wrong notifications to the participants, which is the https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/evolution-data-server/-/issues/551 , but I see it landed for the 3.52.4 too, which you've installed, thus it might be some other action causing this false email.

Does Fastmail handle meeting invitations for you or you've the cancellation notice in your Sent mails in the Evolution, please? The CalDAV calendar Properties has an option whether the server handles the invitation mails or not.

note.body: Emacs could use `.editorconfig` with a plugin.  But nevertheless it evaluates the first line of each file, which in EDS often it is „Mode: C; tab-width: 8; indent-tabs-mode: t; c-basic-offset: 8“, however in some files this line is missing.  So adding this file will abolish the need to insert the mode-line in each file. If the `.editorconfig` file is supposed to be used by emacs, then everywhere the line `mode: c…` should be removed, so that it does not appear in new files.

Thanks for a bug report. The gnutls code is not called directly and from the name it seems to me it's some global memory being initialized, but I can be wrong.

For the other one, hard to say.

What version of the eds do you use, please? How did you stop the processes, please? The source registry does not stop itself, in contrast to the factories, which can close itself after 10 seconds of no client being connected to it. Closing the processes with a SIGTERM is possible, but it's not a graceful close (even it should not leak memory).
